Adding client-side Javascript into Hello World

In the previous unit, we created a CSS resource concept and included it in the "Hello World" concept. In this unit, you can add a Javascript resource to that page by following these steps:

  1. Open the Hello World concept in the IDE mode.
  2. Open the Finder using the navigation bar on the top right.
  3. Select the Hello World concept in the Finder, and use the Add button, on the panel to its right, to add a "New Javascript" under the concept.
  4. In the viewer, set the file name to "hello-world.js" and enter the following Javascript content into the text box. 
    $(function() {
  $("h1").animate({ "fontSize": "8em" }, 5000);
});
  5. Save the changes in the Viewer.
  6. Click the next to "My Second Concept" in the Finder, and select the "Edit" option to open the concept in the Editor.
  7. Refactor the concept in the Editor, by moving the HTML defined within the page property to a simple property in the concept, using the following steps:
    1. Add a simple property in "My Second Concept" called html using the Add button next to "Simple Properties".
    2. Set the property name to "html", its type to String, its mode to "HTML mode", and the value to the html specified in the page property.
    3. Drag-and-drop the html property in the Simple Properties section to rearrange it to be defined before the page property.
    4. Change the page's html property from a String to a property value ( ) and set the property to be looked up as html.
  8. Save the changes made during the refactoring.
  9. Copy the resource URI of the Javascript resource shown in the Viewer using the Ctrl-C (Windows, Linux) or Command-C (Mac) keystrokes.
  10. Back in the Editor, change the html property as shown below, and save the changes. 
    <head>...</head>
<body>
  ...
  <script src="[ENTER RESOURCE URI]" type="text/javascript"></script>
</body>
  11. Use the menu next to "My Second Concept" in the Editor's header to view the updated Hello World concept. You should now see the animated version of the Hello World.

How it works

The Javascript resource concept works similar to the CSS resource concept. You can open the Javascript concept in the Debugger to see how it establishes indirect is-a relationships to the following core concepts:

  1. Web Resource: This ensures that the /resource/... URL delivers the Javascript with the correct content type.
  2. Named Resource: This ensures that the concept is renamed to the given filename.
  3. HTML Page: This provides the user interface based on the ACE editor to edit the Javascript content outside the IDE.

The following video shows how you can use the debugger to understand the internals of the JS resource concept.

Using Javascript from CDNs

The easiest way to add external Javascript references is to link your HTML to a publicly available URL from a CDN (content delivery network), such as maxcdn or cdnjs. For example, you can include the code for moment.js by adding this line to your HTML. 

  <script src="https://cdnjs.cloudflare.com/ajax/libs/moment.js/2.8.4/moment.min.js" type="text/javascript"></script>

Recap

  • The Finder supports an Add Javascript resource option that lets you create your own JS resources.
  • JS resource concepts can be edited in the presentation mode, or using the viewer or editor in the IDE.
  • Like CSS resources, you can link Javascript resources using their resource URI, which is formed by '/resource' followed by the concept URI. The easiest way to access the resource URI is to look at the JS resource concept in the viewer or in presentation mode.
  • If the Javascript file is accessible in a CDN, you can directly include the URL in the <head> tag of the HTML page.

In the next unit, we will add some data elements to the Hello World page.
